paragraph: The Tale of the Flopsy Bunnies Beatrix Potter
FOR ALL LITTLE FRIENDS
OF
MR. MCGREGOR & PETER & BENJAMIN
BOOK 1.
It is said that the effect of eating too much lettuce is "soporific."
tokens: say effect eat much lettuce soporific

paragraph: _I_ have never felt sleepy after eating lettuces; but then _I_ am not a rabbit.
They certainly had a very soporific effect upon the Flopsy Bunnies!
When Benjamin Bunny grew up, he married his Cousin Flopsy. They had a large family, and they were very improvident and cheerful.
tokens: grow marry cousin have large family improvident cheerful

paragraph: I do not remember the separate names of their children; they were generally called the "Flopsy Bunnies."
As there was not always quite enough to eat,--Benjamin used to borrow cabbages from Flopsy's brother, Peter Rabbit, who kept a nursery garden.
tokens: be enough eat use borrow cabbage brother keep nursery garden

paragraph: Sometimes Peter Rabbit had no cabbages to spare.
When this happened, the Flopsy Bunnies went across the field to a rubbish heap, in the ditch outside Mr. McGregor's garden.
tokens: happen go field rubbish heap ditch garden

paragraph: Mr. McGregor's rubbish heap was a mixture. There were jam pots and paper bags, and mountains of chopped grass from the mowing machine (which always tasted oily), and some rotten vegetable marrows and an old boot or two. One day--oh joy!--there were a quantity of overgrown lettuces, which had "shot" into flower.
tokens: rubbish heap mixture be jam pot paper bag mountain choppe grass mowing machine taste oily rotten vegetable marrow old boot day joy be quantity overgrown lettuce have shot flower

paragraph: The Flopsy Bunnies simply stuffed lettuces. By degrees, one after another, they were overcome with slumber, and lay down in the mown grass.
tokens: stuff lettuce degree overcome slumber lay mown grass

paragraph: Benjamin was not so much overcome as his children. Before going to sleep he was sufficiently wide awake to put a paper bag over his head to keep off the flies.
tokens: overcome child go sleep wide awake put paper bag head keep fly

paragraph: The little Flopsy Bunnies slept delightfully in the warm sun. From the lawn beyond the garden came the distant clacketty sound of the mowing machine. The bluebottles buzzed about the wall, and a little old mouse picked over the rubbish among the jam pots.
tokens: little sleep warm sun lawn garden come distant clacketty sound mowing machine bluebottle buzz wall little old mouse pick rubbish jam pot

paragraph: (I can tell you her name, she was called Thomasina Tittlemouse, a woodmouse with a long tail.)
tokens: tell name call woodmouse long tail

paragraph: She rustled across the paper bag, and awakened Benjamin Bunny.
The mouse apologized profusely, and said that she knew Peter Rabbit.

While she and Benjamin were talking, close under the wall, they heard a heavy tread above their heads; and suddenly Mr. McGregor emptied out a sackful of lawn mowings right upon the top of the sleeping Flopsy Bunnies! Benjamin shrank down under his paper bag. The mouse hid in a jam pot.
tokens: talk wall hear heavy tread head empty sackful lawn mowing top sleeping shrank paper bag mouse hide jam pot

paragraph: The little rabbits smiled sweetly in their sleep under the shower of grass; they did not awake because the lettuces had been so soporific.
tokens: little rabbit smile sleep shower grass awake lettuce soporific

paragraph: They dreamt that their mother Flopsy was tucking them up in a hay bed.
Mr. McGregor looked down after emptying his sack. He saw some funny little brown tips of ears sticking up through the lawn mowings. He stared at them for some time.
tokens: look empty sack see funny little brown tip ear stick lawn mowing stare time

paragraph: Presently a fly settled on one of them and it moved.
Mr. McGregor climbed down on to the rubbish heap--

"One, two, three, four! five! six leetle rabbits!" said he as he dropped them into his sack. The Flopsy Bunnies dreamt that their mother was turning them over in bed. They stirred a little in their sleep, but still they did not wake up.
tokens: leetle rabbit say drop sack dreamt mother turn bed stirr little sleep wake

paragraph: Mr. McGregor tied up the sack and left it on the wall.
He went to put away the mowing machine.
While he was gone, Mrs. Flopsy Bunny (who had remained at home) came across the field.
She looked suspiciously at the sack and wondered where everybody was?
Then the mouse came out of her jam pot, and Benjamin took the paper bag off his head, and they told the doleful tale.
tokens: mouse come jam pot take paper bag head tell doleful tale

paragraph: Benjamin and Flopsy were in despair, they could not undo the string.
But Mrs. Tittlemouse was a resourceful person. She nibbled a hole in the bottom corner of the sack.
tokens: resourceful person nibble hole bottom corner sack

paragraph: The little rabbits were pulled out and pinched to wake them.
Their parents stuffed the empty sack with three rotten vegetable marrows, an old blacking-brush and two decayed turnips.
tokens: parent stuff empty sack rotten vegetable marrow old blacking brush decay turnip

paragraph: Then they all hid under a bush and watched for Mr. McGregor.
Mr. McGregor came back and picked up the sack, and carried it off.
He carried it hanging down, as if it were rather heavy.
The Flopsy Bunnies followed at a safe distance.
The watched him go into his house.
And then they crept up to the window to listen.
Mr. McGregor threw down the sack on the stone floor in a way that would have been extremely painful to the Flopsy Bunnies, if they had happened to have been inside it.
tokens: throw sack stone floor way painful happen

paragraph: They could hear him drag his chair on the flags, and chuckle--
"One, two, three, four, five, six leetle rabbits!" said Mr. McGregor.
"Eh? What's that? What have they been spoiling now?" enquired Mrs. McGregor.
"One, two, three, four, five, six leetle fat rabbits!" repeated Mr. McGregor, counting on his fingers--"one, two, three--"
tokens: leetle fat rabbit repeat count finger

paragraph: "Don't you be silly; what do you mean, you silly old man?"
"In the sack! one, two, three, four, five, six!" replied Mr. McGregor.
(The youngest Flopsy Bunny got upon the window-sill.)
Mrs. McGregor took hold of the sack and felt it. She said she could feel six, but they must be _old_ rabbits, because they were so hard and all different shapes.
tokens: take hold sack feel say feel _old_ rabbit hard different shape

paragraph: "Not fit to eat; but the skins will do fine to line my old cloak."
tokens: fit eat skin do fine line old cloak

paragraph: "Line your old cloak?" shouted Mr. McGregor--"I shall sell them and buy myself baccy!"
tokens: line old cloak shout sell buy baccy

paragraph: "Rabbit tobacco! I shall skin them and cut off their heads."
Mrs. McGregor untied the sack and put her hand inside.
When she felt the vegetables she became very very angry. She said that Mr. McGregor had "done it a purpose."
tokens: feel vegetable become angry say do purpose

paragraph: And Mr. McGregor was very angry too. One of the rotten marrows came flying through the kitchen window, and hit the youngest Flopsy Bunny.
tokens: angry rotten marrow come fly kitchen window hit young

paragraph: It was rather hurt.
Then Benjamin and Flopsy thought that it was time to go home.
So Mr. McGregor did not get his tobacco, and Mrs. McGregor did not get her rabbit skins.
But next Christmas Thomasina Tittlemouse got a present of enough rabbit-wool to make herself a cloak and a hood, and a handsome muff and a pair of warm mittens.
tokens: next get present enough rabbit wool make cloak hood handsome muff pair warm mitten
